result.markdown:
---
eval: true
code-fold: false
engine: knitr
---








# R basics

In this chapter we will introduce to the R basics and some exercises to get familiar to how R works.

## Simple operations








::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Sum
1+1
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 2
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# Substraction
10-4
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 6
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# Multiplication
2*2
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 4
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# Division
6/2
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 3
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Combination of numbers
c(1, 2, 3)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 1 2 3
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
c(1:3)  # The ":" means from the number of the left to the one on the right
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 1 2 3
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Round the number
round(3.14)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 3
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
round(3.14, 1) #the "1" indicates that you want only one digit after the dot. 
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 3.1
```


:::
:::

::: {.cell}

:::
